candidates.reason: The comment discusses electronics and a motor control, but does not mention the repetition of 'Let's go' or any context related to the topic title.
candidates.comment: Starts off with using a large heat sink to mount his mosfet and rectifiers, along with a potentiometer, there are several videos where people just solder the component to each other without using a board for a base. I guess this is an easier way to do, but it seems a little sloppy to me. It is very interesting to see the control of the motor with very little electronics. The motor is moving pretty fast for only a hand full of electronics used. I do wonder how hot the mosfet was controlling the motor.
candidates.url: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CvMDlG_AF3Q: how to make simple dc motor speed control circuit

candidates.comment: In order to build a simple DC motor speed control circuit, you will need the following materials a MOSFET, a potentiometer, a resistor, a power supply of a 25 voltage, a multimeter, a soldering iron, and wires. In order to assemble the circuit, you start by connecting a wire to the MOSFET. Next you connect the middle pin of the MOSFET to the resistor and the other end of the resistor to the middle pin of the potentiometer. The other pins of the potentiometer can be connected to wires. One will be connected to the MOSFET and the other to the pin will be used to attach the power supply and the multimeter. When all of those connections are made the multimeter will be able to read the voltage going across the circuit. Finally, you can attach the DC motor to the circuit, and it will start spinning due to the correct assembly of the circuit.
candidates.url: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CvMDlG_AF3Q: how to make simple dc motor speed control circuit.
